text:
Python package management is a utter mess.
I am trying to run JuPyTer, which is installed in Python 3.9.
It is failing because it tries to start the kernel in Python 3.7 (which doesn’t have have jupyter installed).
Why is it trying to use 3.7? I am not entirely sure, but i think it is something to do with them trying to escape the virtual enviroment.

Turns out stacked enviroments are really useful.

text:
and as far as I can tell the answer is to install yet another python enviroment management tool.
This time pyenv.

But I think I got into this mess because:
I have both system python and homebrew python.
So obviously, the solution is a 3rd tool that will create even more python installs…

apparently i am now installing yet another version of python, 3.8 this time.
and it is hauling down all of X??? and rust?? What is going on…

text: Seriously this must be what it feels like to when people start with julia and run into something they don’t get something. Like the confused post where people use `include` 3 times in the same project, or are like  “julia is super slow” (because time to first plot).

text:
Or maybe it isn’t?
Maybe even if you are good at python managing your installs and PATH is always a pain?

I give up.
I am just never going to be able to run a python program.

text: Or perhaps python users got used to python quirks and adapted to them just like we got used and adapted to Julia quirks

elements.text: Or perhaps python users got used to python quirks and adapted to them just like we got used and adapted to Julia quirks

text: There's something weird going on. I mean, on my development VM, I've got system Python, two Linuxbrew Pythons, and various Pyenv-installed Pythons installed, and I never have an issue running Jupyter. That said, I don't have Jupyter installed globally. Instead, I have Jupyter installed separately in every virtual environment where I need it (with Poetry I just install it as a dev dependency, so it doesn't pollute the actual dependencies of the project). It is a bit of a waste of hard drive space, but at least it works.

elements.text: There's something weird going on. I mean, on my development VM, I've got system Python, two Linuxbrew Pythons, and various Pyenv-installed Pythons installed, and I never have an issue running Jupyter. That said, I don't have Jupyter installed globally. Instead, I have Jupyter installed separately in every virtual environment where I need it (with Poetry I just install it as a dev dependency, so it doesn't pollute the actual dependencies of the project). It is a bit of a waste of hard drive space, but at least it works.

text: By the way, pyenv isn't a Python environment manager, it's a Python version manager. In the same way that you can use asdf to manage Julia versions (in fact, you could use asdf to manage Python versions as well. Pyenv is just a Python-specific version manager).

elements.text: By the way, pyenv isn't a Python environment manager, it's a Python version manager. In the same way that you can use asdf to manage Julia versions (in fact, you could use asdf to manage Python versions as well. Pyenv is just a Python-specific version manager).

text: Still, I agree with your original statement: stacked environments are really useful!

elements.text: Still, I agree with your original statement: stacked environments are really useful!

text:
I use Conda (Mamba, really), but I'm not that excited about it. It seems to just barely work for what I'm doing.
<@UPSSPPBFV> did you say once you recommended Poetry as a Python environment manager?

elements.text: I use Conda (Mamba, really), but I'm not that excited about it. It seems to just barely work for what I'm doing.
did you say once you recommended Poetry as a Python environment manager?

text: <@U7HAYKY9X> Yeah, I did. At least for me, it works very well (or at least as well as one can expect for a Python tool :stuck_out_tongue:). Its development started recently, so it's not handicapped by the cruft that a tool like Mamba has to handle to stay compatible with Conda. Underlyingly, it's just a powerful environment and dependency management layer on top of venv and pip (as well as a build and publish tool), so it doesn't have incompatibility issues with standard Python tools like Conda has. And it works well with whatever version of Python you have active at the moment.

elements.text: Yeah, I did. At least for me, it works very well (or at least as well as one can expect for a Python tool

). Its development started recently, so it's not handicapped by the cruft that a tool like Mamba has to handle to stay compatible with Conda. And it works well with whatever version of Python you have active at the moment.

text: Neat. I'll give it a try next time I get into snakey-trouble.

text:
>  Or perhaps python users got used to python quirks and adapted to them just like we got used and adapted to Julia quirks
That is my primary thesis.
but the alternative possibility is this always sucks.
I can’t really say for sure if this gets better or not.
(which itself is also something I imaging people new to julia feel)

text:
I am hearing all these words like version manager and package manager and Conda and Mambo and PyEnv and Poetry and VirtualEnviroment.

Do I really have to understand all these things to use a simple python program?
THis is a common data science task!
I can’t imagine this language ever taking off for data science if I need to learn all this random sysadmin stuff before I can even get started

elements.text:
I am hearing all these words like version manager and package manager and Conda and Mambo and PyEnv and Poetry and VirtualEnviroment.

Do I really have to understand all these things to use a simple python program?
THis is a common data science task!
I can’t imagine this language ever taking off for data science if I need to learn all this random sysadmin stuff before I can even get started

text: I know you're being sarcastic, but yeah, you kind of have to understand at least some of this stuff, just like you have to understand Pkg to be able to really use Julia. The only difference is that Pkg is part and parcel of Julia so you're not likely to see alternatives pop up that easily, while for Python package management has historically been a separate thing, and only relatively recently things have started to move towards integration (and then only partially. No Python package management nor build tool is part of the Python standard library).

elements.text: I know you're being sarcastic, but yeah, you kind of have to understand at least some of this stuff, just like you have to understand Pkg to be able to really use Julia. The only difference is that Pkg is part and parcel of Julia so you're not likely to see alternatives pop up that easily, while for Python package management has historically been a separate thing, and only relatively recently things have started to move towards integration (and then only partially. No Python package management nor build tool is part of the Python standard library).

text: So the result is that you get plenty of alternatives to choose from.

elements.text: So the result is that you get plenty of alternatives to choose from.

text: Isn't choice great? :troll:

elements.text: Isn't choice great?

text: now i am feeling that thing new julia users complain about where there are too many options for X (e.g. tabular data, fancy arrays) and I just want one that works and I want that to be in the standard library

text: Yup, that's pretty much it. But at least Julia doesn't have "there should be one --and preferably only one-- obvious way to do it" as part of its design principles. Python does. :stuck_out_tongue:

elements.text: Yup, that's pretty much it. But at least Julia doesn't have "there should be one --and preferably only one-- obvious way to do it" as part of its design principles. Python does.

text: That view has been expressed a number of times by the creators of Julia

elements.text: That view has been expressed a number of times by the creators of Julia

text: But they haven't made it gospel like the creator of Python has.

elements.text: But they haven't made it gospel like the creator of Python has.

text: Also, Python's from the 90's. I bet the story with dependencies was different back then.

elements.text: Also, Python's from the 90's. I bet the story with dependencies was different back then.

text: Very much so. I mean, my first attempt at learning Python (very much as a hobbyist at the time) was back in 2003 if I remember correctly. At that time, people were only _starting_ to think about package management and dependencies (even `easy_install` wouldn't be released before 2004!). I eventually left Python for Ruby (which was also looking into the issue of package management at the time) so I didn't follow the development of Python that much, but even `pip` itself is only becoming 10 years old this year.

text:
Agree’d.
a strong built in package management story is one of the defining traits in my mind of a modern (postmodern?) language.
Julia, Rust, Go, all have this in common.

elements.text:
Agree’d.
a strong built in package management story is one of the defining traits in my mind of a modern (postmodern?) language.
Julia, Rust, Go, all have this in common.

text: Very true. But it's thanks to the struggles of those previous generations of languages like Python and Ruby (not to forget Haskell) that we now know a language needs an integrated package management story and consider it a defining trait of a modern language.

elements.text: Very true. But it's thanks to the struggles of those previous generations of languages like Python and Ruby (not to forget Haskell) that we now know a language needs an integrated package management story and consider it a defining trait of a modern language.

text: <@UB7JS9CHF> I have heard them say that, but I don't understand it WRT to julia, because the language seems like it's designed the opposite way. For instance `map(f,lst)` is by design equivalent to `[f(x) for x in lst]`.

elements.text: I have heard them say that, but I don't understand it WRT to julia, because the language seems like it's designed the opposite way. For instance

text: I think that it is a goal, but two things: there were 4 co-creators, with sometimes differing opinions, instead of a BDFL, and they are pragmatic, which is a very good thing, IMO

attachments.title: Python Environment
attachments.text: [Title text] "The Python environmental protection agency wants to seal it in a cement chamber, with pictorial messages to future civilizations warning them about the danger of using sudo to install random Python packages."
